reviewText:
A Fistful of Fun
This is a shooter quite like no other. The Wild West themed bullet circus is utterly insane and enjoyable. All the mechanics of the game feel finely tuned and precise: dodging bullets and sending them back feels so intuitive you should never have to stand there and bleed. The levels and areas are all varied and peppered with details and events such as carrying a giant explosive piñata, robbing banks, dodging rolling crates and so on. The structure of the game has these different level types shuffled around and enemy placement is randomized, but this only one small part of what keeps the action fun and exciting throughout.

The playable characters are a definite highlight of the game. While most games might settle for differentiating characters by stats or looks alone, the colorful cast of a Fistul also has different styles based around the actual input and control of the character: you have a shotgun toting teacher whose two barrels need to be reloaded individually,  the wanted outlaw Billy who wields twin revolvers that only fire when the highlighted chamber is pressed, Bomberman fans will feel right at home playing as Pablo the demo daredevil and this is barely scratching the surface. Each character feels vastly different from the next and they all come with some alternative weapons that can be picked up in the game. Mastering each gunslinger bit by bit feels immensely satisfying and the only problem is deciding which one is your huckleberry.

However, strong characters would be wasted if they didn't have some clever enemies to go up against and Fistful delivers on this front as well. Machine gun wagons, rabid bears, magic arrows, among others, are all a great match up against the heroes of Fistful. However, even the more standard gunslinging enemies keep things interesting as they will move about the map, flank you, set of explosives, and shoot behind cover. To help out against the overwhelming amount of bullets, the game also has powerups in the form of different whiskey that can give you a chance to ignore a bullet or make one of your own explode. Even with powerups though, you will need to hone your skills to keep your continues from running dry.

This shooter has a sure sense of style. The narrowing wide screen, red tones throughout, panning shots, acid wild west colors, arcade font and voice over, and old west monologues all come together nicely to bring out a sense of the legendary west. The soundtrack also does a fantastic piece of Morricone inspired tunes. The chants, whistling and marching drums go along nicely with the rest of the aesthetics.

The local and online co-op are both fun experiences and each mode available is pure hectic fun. However, the 9 player local co-op is really more for laughs than ever actually accomplishing anything in the game. That being said playing in a group as The Magnificent Seven or going at it on your lonesome like The Man with No Name, there is a good time to be had. The story and arcade modes, aside from cutscenes and a definite ending, differ between some shuffled around mechanics and events (such as how upgrades work and taking peyote). Aside from unlocking characters in story mode, there are also safes that have a chance to drop new locations that get shuffled into the gameplay mix. The versus mode is a great way to let your friends know that this living room ain't big enough for the 2-9 of you. The different modes, unlocks, and urge to be better all go a long way in replay value.

As far as pure arcade madness goes, A Fistful of Gun has no equal.  The top down shooting action, whether alone or in co-op, is frantic, adrenaline fueled, and challenging.

*Note: as an owner of Under the Ocean that did not refund my game, I was able to receive a free key from the developer ( See here for more info ). However, this does not affect my review of the game at all.

reviewText:
Review Date: Thursday, 18th February 2016
Hours played prior to reviewing: 12.6
Achievement progress: 15/36 | 43%

Review
Welcome to the Wild West! A Fistful Of Gun is a fast-paced top-down shooter with rogue-like elements separated into 2 main modes: Arcade and Story. There's 11 different characters to choose from, each of them comes with unique controls and their own fighting system. The game has full controller support but for some characters you have to switch to keyboard & mouse, otherwise the game won't let you play them. When you start up the western action for the first time, you most likely begin with Arcade Mode that lets you pick all of those characters. Which is nice for practice purposes but can be terrible if your first choice is one of the guys with very odd controls. I have to admit I rage-quitted the game after two short runs of Arcade because I thought there's something wrong with the Steam Controller bindings (I'm using a template from the community). The character 'Noah' was the reason for it though. He's on the very left of the character select screen and why would you not start from the left?
Well, obviously I gave the game another shot after checking the discussions and finding that other cowboys play very differently. I didn't regret starting it again because I found myself getting addicted to this little gem. Let me know tell you more about the main modes:

Arcade: You can select any character and start on a warm-up map. The goal is to clear the screen to get to the next one and reach the highest score. The maps and enemies are randomized but get significantly more difficult over the time. After you cleared a screen, the game gives you the option to choose among 5 random upgrades to make yourself stronger. One shot or hit of an enemy kills you and takes a life (in form of a card). You start with five hearts but a horse - that you can either steal from an enemy or get through an upgrade - or an armor upgrade take 1 bullet instead of you which basically means an extra life. Arcade can be played in single-player, local and online multiplayer.

Story: Unlike Arcade mode, you can only pick one of the three already unlocked wranglers to start your journey with. The goal is to reach the 3rd chapter and kill the railroad baron Clayton Boon, the reason for all our troubles along the way. Each chapter ends with a unique boss fight and is 14 miles (= 14 screens) away from the start. Just as in the other mode, the enemies, type of maps and events are randomized, although you decide which direction you want to continue on. But keep in mind: There is no going back. Coins that you collect can be spent on several things such as new weapons, upgrades, playing cards (very important to increase the amount of your lives).  Unfortunately the story can only be played alone or in local co-op and there is no support for playing it online.

★☆━━━━━━━━━[RATING: 8/10]━━━━━━━━━☆★

Positive
Pixelart / Graphics: I adore them. The gunslingers have been designed with love and look super cute despite them being badass killers with moustaches and all. The maps itself lacks a bit of details on first glance - but honestly, it would make the bullethell just more confusing.
Gameplay: The gameplay is incredibly fun if you learn how to play with the characters and pick one that you like. You will get addicted to Story mode after experiencing new things you haven't seen before and secrets that still need to be revealed.
Easter Eggs: It would be too spoiling to reveal too much, just let me tell you there's a lot of stuff randomly going on that you wouldn't predict and that will make you laugh for sure.
Soundtrack: The soundtrack fits the setting well and is neither annoying nor too minimal, they really did a good job balancing it.
Events: The developer organizes special community events occasionally. Unfortunately I couldn't participate in any yet but I hope another one is happening soon! (These events are required to obtain some of the achievements)
Steam features: Achievements - check, Trading Cards - check. Perfect! Cloud saving might useful to some players, I personally didn't need it. Workshop support would be pointless for this game.
Neutral
Difficulty: A Fistful Of Gun is not easy. Not at all. In almost 13 hours of playtime I still haven't beaten the campaign yet. I lost 30 lives in some screens and died because they really were impossible with the setup / loot I had. You need luck to get gold, to find a merchant and card players and you need luck with the screens you land on. Challenging games can be good and make you become ambitious but sometimes it felt like a pain in the ♥♥♥.. The achievements are (too) hard and rare as well.
Negative
Mac / Linux Support: Not available. Every game should have support for all platforms on Steam or at least offer support for one additional OS.
Online Story Co-Op: You can only play Arcade and Versus online with friends. But the focus should be on the story and that mode can only be played alone or in local co op.

reviewText:
Short Version:  A short, but highly replayable and entertaining multi-directional shoot-em-up in the tradition of Smash TV.  Great fun for a few bouts with friends now and then, but only buy solo if you're really into this type of game.

In a Fistful of Gun you can get together with a few trigger-happy friends to play with guns, get drunk, break stuff, and blow up angry chickens with dynamite all without the real-life consequences!  You choose from one of 11 different characters to run through random levels of retro gunslinging action, grabbing as many gold nuggets, power-ups and alcoholic boosts along the way as you can.

One of the biggest draws of the game is the multiplayer aspect, with high-score progress designed to track a full posse of players.  This is emphasized even further by the unforgiving gameplay, which can cause the 'continue' screen to pop up rather often in solo mode.  Even though bullets are too scarce in many stages to push this into bullet-hell territory, between the heat-seeking farm animals of doom, stray crates of dynamite, and of course a horde of guntoting baddies, you WILL die.  Simply completing the relatively short single-player story mode (which is truthfully about as story-less as a story mode can be) might take some practice.

Of course, once a playthrough ends, the secondary hook of Fistful of Gun may very well entice you into another round;  Each of the eleven different characters to choose from features a different gun, which is actually an entirely new control scheme and shooting style.  One gunslinger fires large shotgun blasts, but only in the direction you're currently running and limited to a single shot in each barrel, while another wields a 6-shooter that can be quickly fired in any direction, but requires joystick flicking and a lengthy reload period after you empty the chamber.  Each of the guns requires you to learn a new set of skills, so perfecting them all could provide a very lengthy challenge.

All in all, Fistful of Gun is a fun, difficult game reminiscent of old school shooters, but with modern features added to boost entertainment and replayability.  If you're buying it purely for solo play, you might want to wait for a decent sale or be certain you enjoy this type of game - a short Story Mode, and a highly replayable but somewhat repetitive Arcade Mode designed around high scores might leave you feeling that the experience was a bit lacking. However, if you love retro shoot-em-ups or have a few friends to play with, A Fistful of Gun could be a blast.

reviewText:
A Fistful of Gun - The Righteous Review
A few months ago I found a stream on twitch by this guy, Paul Hart, whom I had never heard about before. He was designing some graphics that seem to be based around the wonderful Sergio Leone spaghetti westerns of the 1960s, The Good The Bad and The Ugly, A fistful of Dollars, Once Upon a Time in America and others. In the background he was also streaming some music from those same films by the incredible Ennio Morricone. The art was good. The art was very good. I then realised this was not just some static images, this was all for a game that he was also developing. I have to admit, I was instantly hooked. My favourite movie genre was being recreated in my favourite pastime, video gaming.

Fast forward a few months to present time and I get to present to you the A Fistful of Gun review and if asked to sum up my feelings in one word, that word would be, wow.

A Fistful of Gun – For a Few Gun More, is in simple terms a top down shooter where you and up to nine, yes nine, other players get to wield the baddest, most righteous gunslingers in the wicked wild west. Simple terms however do this game no justice, A Fistful of Gun is one of the most frenetic, hilarious, addictive and complete video games I have ever had the pleasure to play.

To say that Fistful of Gun is a multiplayer game would be doing it a severe injustice though at it’s heart it really is meant to be played with others, both locally through a wonderful system of couch co-op or online with fully optimised net code. Have no fears that this is yet another Indie game with tacked on online play as it is not, Fistful of Gun plays incredibly well online and offers a wealth of modes and fun, however I shall start with the story mode.

Taking the role of one of eleven characters you play the part of a lone gunman with one task, to stop the evil railroad Baron, Clayton Boon, and avenge the ‘righteous psychosis’ of those he has wronged. To do this you must traverse thirteen miles of barren western deserts, hokey townships, corrupt lawmen, arrow toting red Indians and much much more. Along the way you will find pickups to upgrade your guns, barrels of Whiskey that really test your drunken gun-slinging skills, and even a very powerful drug induced high that will have you trippin’ all the way to your characters tombstone. After it’s initial release we are also promised access to Spirit Animals to help you on your quest. All of this is done through a top down, almost bullet hell game play filled with colour, and extremely pretty pixel styled graphics that invoke a retro gaming feel but a very modern and fast gaming experience.

Levels in A Fistful of Gun vary extensively in looks and feel and you will find that what worked on the previous one will not do so on the next. This makes the game feel fresh every time you progress and each play-through is always a little different which can and will keep you coming back for more. Top this off with an excellent high score list that keeps track of all global players and your friends and you have more than one reason to keep coming back for more.

In addition to the single player Story section of the game we also have Local and Online Arcade mode which involves multiple levels of gunslinger action across all the varied themed areas and with harder A.I. as you progress. The arcade mode can also be played solo or with up to nine other players through online play or Fistfuls unique control style where all nine players can couch around just the one PC and use a combination of purely mouse control, pure keyboard control and of course full game controller support. I won’t lie, the controls can get confusing and each character has varying ways of being played so for some a controller is the only way, for others mouse and keyboard is your only option. This forces players to prefer one character over another but with eleven to choose from there is always a character for everyone’s style and abilities.

The other main online mode is Versus and as the name suggests it is you versus everyone else but as this is A Fistful of Gun the areas are also spiced up with TNT, Trains, Mexican outlaws and much more, all designed to make your job of killing your opponents as hard as possible and as much fun as it can be, and believe me it is fun!

Online play is done through dedicated servers and also includes the ability to create your own server on your PC using the included server.exe which is a rare thing these days and I applaud the developer Paul Hart for designing the game around this option from day one. It is both refreshing and inspiring to see more indie developers do this. Online play through either the dedicated or personal server is fast and easy to use from my pre-release tests and due to the inclusion of the server.exe I see no reason why this should not continue.

Often overlooked in indie games is the audio and whilst the actual audio options are simplistic for Fistful of Gun the actual music, audio clips and voice acting are not. There is an inspired choice of musical style here that jumps from excellent heavy rock when needed to a more traditional Ennio Morricone spaghetti western theme that invokes even more memories of those classical movies. The voices used, whilst a small selection fit the genre perfectly too and just help to make the game feel like one of the most complete experiences I have had in many years.

The options are somewhat basic with little choice in resolution or effects but like many games of this ilk they really are not needed and will max out on virtually any PC from the last three to four years with ease with an option to drop the quality for older machines whilst still looking and playing gloriously.

Released for Windows PC that also includes a raft of Steam achievements and trading cards this game is an absolute steal and my biggest must buy of 2015.

Strap on your belt, load up your six shooter. There is a new Multiplayer Game Of The Year and it is called A Fistful of Gun – For a Few Gun More.

Buy this game, now!

reviewText:
Wild Wild West shoot 'em up / bullet hell arcade style game that is both extremely frustrating and fun to play.
Fun because it is pure adrenaline rush! Fast paced, “kill or be killed” action. Each level takes from a couple of seconds to a couple of minutes to clear.
Frustrating because you take one hit, you die and have to restart the level. There is no health bar. Once you run out of lives, game over.
Singleplayer is okay, however multiplayer with friends (online or local co-op) is when this game really shines.
Visually it looks pretty good (I love pixel graphics in general), but not great. Everything is a little too tiny to my taste and lacks detail. Good music and sound. There is not much “story” to the story mode. All you need to know is that you are an outlaw and everyone wants to kill you.

Pros:
Fun, addicting and fast-paced gameplay.
Multiple characters with different weapons.
Randomly generated levels, each playthrough is different.
Many things to unlock / purchase.
Awesome boss fights.

Cons:
Very steep difficulty curve.
Story is lacking.
No save option.
Can get repetitive.

Overall: Singleplayer experience 6/10; with friends 8/10.

When starting up A Fistful of Gun for the first time I was greeted with retro style pixel graphics combined with the dusty zest of an old Western movie. I grabbed my controller and jumped right in, since there was no tutorial, and promptly died. The game is a top down shooter that is very much like a bullet hell game. Shots are flying every which way as you run around killing bad guys and picking up the gold left behind. Despite being horrible at this sort of game I still found it fun and enjoyable, albeit frustrating. It’s a good game to pick up every now and again, especially to play with friends.

There is a story to the game but I won’t lie, I didn’t pay too much attention to it. From what I gathered there is a rich railroad baron named Cayton Boon and he’s making life miserable so a group of sharp shooters are after him. I am unsure if all of the characters know each or not, due to me not being very good at the game I didn’t progress very far in the story. There are currently three acts to the story and a fourth act coming shortly.

Where the game truly shines is arcade mode which I enjoyed a lot more than the story mode. You progress through short levels and at the end of each you can upgrade your character, making their shots hit harder or giving them protection from fire. You can also play with a friend go for versus mode, or even hop online to play with others. The game offers a fun experience alone but is even better with others. Whatever mode you play, you have the choice between eleven unique characters. You can use a controller or your mouse and keyboard though I preferred the controller. Each character offers a different play style, some use guns, others use bombs and one is actually a whole regiment of soldiers that loses a soldier with every hit. I loved the variety, however the game has no tutorial or training mode so the only way to learn is through trial and error.

The game has a decent user interface, but sometimes the text can be a bit tiny, such as when you’re selecting an upgrade in arcade mode. The graphics are great, it’s like a pixelated spaghetti Western in all of its cheesy glory. However, sometimes with all the action going on at the screen at once it can become a chaotic mess and disorienting, however that’s what most bullet hell games seem like to me. The music is very fitting of the game, has a great Western vibe to it and brings the package together well. You can buy the soundtrack separately if you like.

While a good game the price seems a bit high for what it currently offers. However, if you find this on sale or in a bundle then go for it. If you enjoy bullet hell style games or top down shooters this should be a fun experience for you. A Fistful of Guns is a campy throwback to old Western films using the modern medium of video games. It’s a great game to play with friends with a lot of variety, it also has Steam achievements and trading cards for you collectors out there.

Sigh …

Or sister?

Hey don't judge!

Important Note: It seems like the achievements are bugged. I've cleared the first act and I survived a Petoye Trip and other things but nothing. I will remove this line once it's been fixed.

StoryTaken straight from the store page:

When the evil railroad baron Clayton Boon decided to build a track to Hell, he didn’t reckon on a crazed shaman raising a posse of embittered psychopaths from the dead to stop him. Now they’ll pursue him across the whole Wild West, fighting their way through hordes of bandits, bears, braves and boogeymen just to find Boon and repay their debt with… A FISTFUL OF GUN!

Do I really have to add anything?

GameplayHere we come to the most important part of the game. Yes you heared that right.
If you take a good look at the Store Page of this game full of psychos then you’ll see that it says Full Controller Support. Well that’s not true. To quote GLaDOS: The Cake is a LieWell actually it isn’t but let me explain. Whether you play with a controller or with your mouse and keyboard is pretty much up to you. However you’ll find yourself hating either of those options very quickly. Depending on the character you’re playing as at the time. For instance I’m playing Noah, our beloved teacher and shotgun aficionado, with a controller while I’m shooting folks as Abel, the record holder for the most squirrels shot in one season, with mouse and keyboard.
So as you see it really is up to you and which option clicks better (see what I did there!?) with the character you’ve fallen in love with you’ve chosen.
Why is that so? Well little Jimmy sit down and listen.
Every character is unique in his own way and you play each in a different way. For example if you play as Zeke, the deranged sniper, you have to make good use of his cloaking ability and of course his sniper rifle. You’ve guessed that right lil’ Jimmy good! Exactly!
While you run pretty much face first into the bullet hell as Noah, you try the best to stay as far away as possible with Zeke.
Oh and by the way the characters I’ve just talked about are the starters, for starters (horrible pun intended). You can unlock others and have even more fun with them later on. There are eleven unique characters in the game which you can all unlock but you have to make due with Noah, Abel and Zeke. Three crazy psychos which love to shoot things (and squirrels).

ModesThe game features different game modes such as Arcade, just kill everything and don’t die, Versus, same as before but vs other people because shooting each other in the face is so much fun!, and a story mode.
Let’s talk about that one since the others are … what they are, duh!
So anyway. After you’ve chosen a character you start on a map, a neutral area. Neutral means that as long as you’re a good boy no one will try to shoot you between your eyes. Then there are other maps where pretty much everyone and everything is trying to kill you. It’s only fair though since you’re trying the same.
Anyway there’re different kind of special maps as well. For example there’s the, what I like to call Stoner Map, where you end up being high and stoned. Pretty fun.
On other maps there are trunks rushing across the screen and everything that gets hit by hit doesn’t live to see another day.
The Story Mode is set up in acts. I haven’t beaten the story mode yet so I don’t know how many but I do know that you can move 12 maps/miles before you’re facing a boss.
Oh and the first one is a real WTF!? moment believe me that.

As you’ve noticed you collect gold which you can use on specific maps to upgrade your character. Be it reload speed, piercing bullets and so on. Everything that you would want. Sometimes the enemkes are dropping Ace of Spades Cards which basically are your Hearts or rather your retries. On some maps you can even buy another Card.
Another note to the skills you unlock. Yes they stay unlocked but only for this specific character!
So don't be too mad once you bite the dust since you can return far greater and stronger than before!

VisualThe game is neat looking. While the enemies pretty much look all the same, the real eye candy are the bosses (or the big ♥♥♥ Pinata you carry on your head sometimes). Characters, bullets, maps everything does its job and reminds you that you’re in one hell of a western my friend!
Overall I’d say that the art style does fit the game and give it some kind of (very) unique charm.

AudioWell it’s weird. Don’t get me wrong it’s your typical western music and all dramatic and heroic and awesome and goofy at the same time but … it’s weird. Or rather the uses of the music is weird. For instance there’s a Rock track that I dig that only plays, rather random, when I’m switching maps. So I always sit here headbanging for like 7 seconds before I get greeted by another tune.
I dig all of them but it’s, at least for me, a bit off putting.
But overall it’s quite a fitting soundtrack.

What else can I say?The real beauty is in the multiplayer I guess. I mean don’t get me wrong the game’s fun and dope and all but the multiplayer’s where it really shines. I mean you can have up to 9 psychos together and just shooting literally everything. I mean I guess so because I haven’t been able to try the multiplayer yet. I’m looking forward to it though.
If you’re a western fan I’d say go grab it. Yes you heared me right El Wizardo go and get it!
Also it's published by Devolver so you should know that you're in for a ride and as I said earlier for quite the dialogues.
Oh another important note. I haven't been a victim of any bugs so far. The game runs smooth and as I said so far I'm bug free ... Yay!

Before we begin it must be said that I have had close contact with the developer throughout production. He is very open and talkative with his fans and took a lot of my pre-release feedback to heart. As a fan I find this refreshing, but also know that because of this it is my duty to disclose that to anyone reading this review.

Fistful of Gun is a rampaging, fast paced shooter full of over the top art, unhealthy levels of alcoholism and thirteen people who can inexplicably all ride the same horse at the same time. It makes no sense, its story is threadbare and the entire game is unbalanced to the point where a newbie can steamroll skilled players just by using an OP character... and I love every minute of it.

Fistful provides an unparalleled level of co-op support for all kinds of play styles. Every single 'gunslinger' has two methods of control, rebind-able keys and a unique weapon with a series of incomprehensible alternate gun pickups to shake things up. You may choose to play with a controller, mouse, keyboard or keyboard and mouse- you may choose to play single player, co-op, verses, online, offline- through a randomly generated and hectic campaign... Fistful is all about choice. Which is great to me.

The only downsides I could think to add is more down to the theme than anything else. The wild west is great, but it likely doesn't provide many options for enemy variety, or map settings. I personally would have liked more missions taking place in a town or tavern just to shake the game up a bit. They exist in story mode, but are not found in arcade (which I consider to be the meat of the game). Overall though what is presented is very solid and there are often a lot of surprises (such as bears) which you will love to find out (not like bears) and others which you will have less positive feelings for (mothertrucking bears).

Overall Fistful of Gun is a solid arcade shooter with many surprises to be had. The sound and music is great, the art style is unique and hilarious and overall I personally think it is worth your time.

reviewText:
Quick View: A Fistful of Gun
”...seems to me like a bagful of fun, doesn`t it?”

Chapter I: Story & Lore:

Welcome to the Wild Wild West, stranger! Do you have what it takes to survive in these rough times? You are here to crush Clayton Boon and his Railroad company. But be aware, rumors say that he made a deal with the devil to kill everybody who is dumb or brave enough to enter his eyesight. Be prepared for a spaghetti western full of evil freaks, not-so-evil freaks, whiskey and - of course - bullets. And horses. And...bullets.

Chapter II: Gameplay & Mechanics

A Fistful of gun offers (very) fast top-down arcade that demands quick eyes and fingers, name it western bullet hell. Choose one of 11 different psychos, each with a unique playstyle, to release the western town from Boons mercyless grasp. Picking your favourite Psycho might rely on your prefered playstyle: Hide, Kill and Hide again? Choose Zeke, The sniper. Unleash a bulletstorm to saw through hordes of enemies? Choose Duke, the man with the chain gun. To do this, you can choose either arcade, story mode or multiplayer via web or local co-op. Story starts with only 3 psychos available since the others need to be unlocked whilst playing. Moving screen by screen you`ll reach Boons hitmen and finally Boon himself whilst collecting gold, finding power ups, alcohol or even finishing some quests. Arcade let`s you pick all available “heroes”, offering a more “endless” feeling with the chance to set your own personal highscore, that can be compared worldwide. Multiplayer is fun to play, works great and makes the game much more enjoyable.

Chapter III: Graphics, Sound & Atmosphere

Soundwise not much to say here: typical wild west soundtrack mixed with the sounds of exploding bombs, srcatching bullets and running horses. I like it!
Graphics might not be everybodys cup of tea but, again, I love it. Wonderfully crafted pixel art that already offers the charm of a 90s classic. Flashy colours, lots of small details and a nice sense of (dark) humour add to the “spaghetti western”-feeling I mentioned earlier.

Chapter IV: Conclusion, Summary & Valuation

Let`s add some negative points here before I valuate. The controls of some playable characters work great with a 360 controller - but not that great whilst playing via keyboard. Vice versa, too. They have to be great because A Fistful of gun can be hard sometimes, even too hard for people who recently started to play. Due to the fact that dying in story mode means starting from the beginning it tends to become repetitive after a while, although not worn off. That said I hope for more active “psychos” for multiplayer. This is not a real negative argument against the game itself but, hands down, A Fistful of Gun is best played in a pack of players, laughing out loud, dying even louder. I hope for a small future discount to attract a wider playerbase.


So, enough explanatory banter! A Fistful of Gun offers hours of fun (and anger), binding you for at least 1-2 hours daily, not to mention if played with friends. Thus said, Multiplayer is highly recommended since the Singleplayer starts to get repetitive unless you try to beat some High Scores.

Indeed, A bagful of fun! 8/10

Disclaimer:  Steam key was provided to me for review purposes.

A Fistful of Gun is the most fun I've had with a top down shooter in quite a while.  The action is fast paced and nearly non-stop, and the old west visuals and music are pure awesome.  It has a bit of a retro feel to it as well, like a game Capcom could've developed for arcades in the '90s.

The gameplay is a mixture of top down shooter and bullet hell, but it isn't the typical shooter, so it might not appeal to those who want to dive straight into the action and feel like an invincible gunslinger. Going in guns blazing will quickly lead to your death.   Unlike most top down shooters, you have to take the time to learn how to play; memorize patterns, learn the controls, and use your reflexes.

You start out with a choice of 3 characters in story mode, and you can unlock 8 more.  The characters all play a bit differently from each other, which is great, but the controls can be frustrating:   Some characters use keyboard & mouse, while others use a gamepad.  For now I'm looking at mastering the controls for each character as part of the challenge - it's not hard to learn anyway - but I can't help feel that full gamepad support for all characters would make the game better.

Pros:

+ Fun, action-packed top down shooting.
+ Great music and sound effects.
+ Awesome pixel graphics with a old west theme.
+ Loads of fun to play with a friend, and almost any game that can be played local and online co-op earns a bonus point from me.

Cons:

- Can be a little repetitive.
- Controls need to be streamlined.
- The price seems a bit steep.  In my opinion, they should lower it to $10.00 USD.

This game is a easy 7/10, and something most fans of the genre will have a blast with, as long as they're willing to put a little time into it.

I saw this game on the front page of Steam and being a sucker for westerns I just had to try it out, and boy am I glad I did. As for the gameplay, it is quite fun and generally controls quite well, except for a few of the characters which can be a bit awkward at least on KB+mouse. I think the biggest selling point of the game is it's eleven unique characters, which each have a very different style and are all fun to play; chances are you will find at least one character you enjoy playing. You can play either story, arcade, or versus mode. Story is single player, and has some rogue-like elements, it's actually something like Binding of Issac in that you have to get through X number of squares to reach a boss, and you have to defeat a number of bosses before you reach the final boss, picking up and buying powerups along the way. As you'd probably expect, the story is about as simple as it gets, it is a standard western revenge plot: the head of a railroad company has wronged you and now you are out for blood. Personally I think most of the replayability lies in the arcade mode, where you must clear out as many of the randomized areas you can either by yourself, with friends, or online. As long as there continues to be an online community I think this mode could have some lasting appeal. As for versus mode, I honestly haven't played it yet, though it seems like it could easily fall prey to unbalanced characters.

The art style in this game is fantastic, pixel graphics have been done to death at this point but the visuals of this game manage to capture the aesthetic of spaghetti westerns very well, and considering how rare western games are, even in the realm of indie games, I think the style really holds its own. As for the music, from what I've heard I'm not too impressed honestly, just seems like a bit of a mish-mash between retro game music and Ennio Morricone, but it really doesn't have a style all its own like in say Luckslinger, another indie western-themed game, in any case this isn't that big of a deal.

My Verdict: For a little over the price of a movie, I think you'll probably get your value and then some out of this game, especially if you enjoy westerns or top down shooters.

reviewText:
During my play-through, I've gotten mixed feelings about this game. It's basically a top-down shooter executed quite well. A single hit will kill your character. There's a story mode and an arcade mode. Both give you a number of lives to retry the level. When you run out, you go back to the character selection screen and start from stage 1. I didn't care much for the story, there isn't much of it anyway. This is definitely not a game you would play for its story.

The soundtrack was done really well, it feeds the vibe that you're in a Western. The sound effects were really nice too, they fit great with the actions you're performing.

The pixelated graphics are charming, but at the same time I felt that they were also distracting; mainly due to the colour palletes. My main problem with it was, that because of the amount of enemies constantly shooting at you, it was easy for me to get killed because colours blended in too much.

Also, it being a top-down game the environmental objects are traitorous at times. Some would block your path, which led me to dying a numerous amount of times. While others are just innocent, and you can simply walk over them. This makes sense if you see a bush that does not block your path, but a wall does. But certain objects which I'd consider as solid objects, were passable as well. This just felt too random at times. And considering the small area of movement, the huge amount of enemies coming at you, and the amount of bullets flying around; you don't have the luxury to think about whether something will block you or not. I think the dev should put more effort into making the solid objects more apparent.

A tip that helped me through the initial frustration: Just shoot up the environment to bits at the start of the stage. I'm very happy to see the dev made it possible to do this. Clearing the area of obstacles, made it a lot easier to move around my character. I also really loved that you can use specific environmental objects in your favour to kill the enemies. There are explosives scattered about, which you can blow up and kill enemies in its vicinity. And certain levels contain tree logs in a running stream, which will kill anything on their path down. You can lead the enemies in their path, and they'll take care of a lot of the mess for you. Be careful not to get hit yourself though.

A very big part of frustration for me though, was the inconsistency at crucial moments. Certain areas in the game contains bullethell-like elements, such as a huge amount of projects coming at you at once. Normally, you would try to manoeuvre between them, because running around their trajectory leads to a lot more time lost. But when I try to move between projectiles, and I get killed by its tail... Yeah, I'm not happy with that. To make absolute sure that it wasn't me that was screwing it up, I took a whiskey to gain slow motion (which makes it sooo much easier to manoeuvre around) but even then I had this same thing happen.

Finally, the game also features a local versus mode, and an online multiplayer. But I didn't thread into the multiplayer myself as I don't care for MP in top-down shooters.

tl;dr: Frustrating at the start, once you get a hold of things you will find an enjoyable top-down shooter underneath. Personal grade: 7/10. It is obvious that the dev put a lot of effort into this game. And it's the small things such as angry pigs, dangerous chickens or just smoking some pot with friendly Indians that make me happy. If the dev fixes certain annoyances and bugs, or lowers the price of the game to fit its 'defects', I'd give it a 8.5/10.

==== Should You Buy This Game? ====In this game you choose one, out of eleven (once unlocked), gunslinger to fight your way through the Wild West in order to stop Clayton Boon from building a railroad to Hell. These eleven gunslingers and their vastly different forms of attack is what makes this game fun, crazy and downright brilliant. I definitely recommend purchasing this game. Like many roguelites, it is a very enjoyable time sink with a great amount of replayability. FarmerGnome did a fantastic job developing this game and will be a group I will keep my eye on in the future.

==== First Impressions ====A Fistful of Gun is one of the most unique and addictive indie games I’ve had the pleasure to come across. To truly enjoy the uniqueness of each character and his playstyle, it is heavily advisable to play with the intended control scheme (some use a controller while others use a mouse/m&k although you can play all eleven with any control scheme). For example, to shoot as Abel, you need to keep flicking the right analog stick on a controller while for Two Feather, you must press/hold and release a directional button. A Fistful of Gun has an Arcade, Story and Online mode with the ability to have a friend/friends coop with you. In Arcade/Story mode, you have a set amount of lives (which can be gained in the form of pickups) and once used up, it will be game over.

==== Current State of the Game ====A Fistful of Gun is already well polished. I didn’t notice any bugs throughout my play. I do have a couple suggestions that would be nice if implemented.

Suggestions: Allow the ability to change the difficulty level
Alter entrance topographies so you aren’t immediately pinned in some areas

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Received a key for review purpose

I'm having a lot of fun with A Fistful of Gun. You play as one of eleven characters, each with their own unique weaponry. From shotguns, to pistols, to miniguns, to explosives, you have a variety of different ways to play. You need to adjust your playthrough depending on which character you choose.

The combat and shooting is very nice. This is a bullet-hell esque game where you have to avoid the enemy bullets while killing the enemy. There are different kinds of enemies that require different approaches; Some enemies are killed with one shot, while others are more tanky and take more than one hit.

One thing this game could improve on is creating a tutorial, because it throws you into the combat so suddenly. There are no explanations on what you are supposed to do, or where you're supposed to go. The controls could be made a lot clearer. The first few times I died, it wasn't just because I sucked at the game but because I literally had no idea what I was supposed to do. It would be nice to practice my character a bit before being thrown in-game. However the controls are fairly easy to grasp after a few deaths or so since this game is fast-paced, so you get used to what you have to do fairly quickly.

In the story mode, you start out in a neutral area where you progress by choosing a direction of the screen to go to. You have a general idea of what you're going to do next by the small picture describing what's there. You start with seven lives, and you can gain more by collecting playing cards that you occasionally come upon. You could go to a railroad area, a river, play a card game, meet a merchant, push a cart, save some hostages, unlock a new player, get ambushed, and more.

I know a lot of reviewers aren't recommending this game based off the story mode, but I had fun playing alone. That being said, this game is more fun with friends, so I recommend finding friends to play with. There are not a lot of people playing online, so it's difficult playing an online match.

This game is polished, well made, and a lot of fun to play. I definitely recommend picking this up if you're looking for a fun co-op game to play with friends.

To describe it one sentence:
A Fistful of Gun is an extremely addicting, fast paced, Western-themed pixelized bullet hell with single player arcade, versus, and story modes as well as online/co-op arcade.

Now for a more in-depth review (:

To start off the game, you've got (like I said before) 4 different options:
-Arcade
You're automatically thrown into the action. Shoot as many bandits (or whatever else is thrown at you) as you can. However, you only have 3 lives, so use them wisely. It starts off easy, only a few people coming at you at once. You clear the level assuming the next will only be slightly harder, but suddenly you're being bombarded with enemies on horseback, pigs running around, tnt exploding everywhere, and all your lives are gone. It gets real difficult, real fast, so keep that in mind.
-Story
I haven't played much of the story mode, but from what I've experienced it's nothing like the arcade. It seems to have a slower, gradually increasing pace rather than suddenly spiking in difficulty.
-Versus
Play against a friend!
-Online
Much like classic arcade, but you can play with friends. If you're going to try out this mode, I reccomend getting a group of your friends together to play, as there isn't much of a player base online at any given time.

Character Selection:
You've got 11 completely different, yet equally fun characters to chose from. Each one has a different playstyle, appealing to pretty much everything. You've got a guy that shoots rockets, an archer, an army regiment, a sniper, and many more. I started out playing The 13th (the regiment) as it's easy to play, and I'd reccomend that character for beginners.

Overall, it's a great game and I'm definitely going to be playing it more.

reviewText:
You know that sort of game that's from a genre you don't care about, but you give it a shot anyway and you're really glad you did? A Fistful of Gun is exactly that.

Extremely well polished, from interface to art design, AFoG takes you into a mock-Wild West flick full of arcade action. Whereas almost all such shooters restrict you to one control scheme -- indeed, some build the whole game around it --, AFoG allows you to select from a variety of such schemes, and also wildly varying weapons which directly affect gameplay.

Co-op is a great way to play. The various scenarios you will be playing in have varying gimmicks, and are slightly randomly generated. The scenery affects the action nicely, and the existence of power-ups also spices things up. So it has the usual shooter props, plus several great additions of its own.

The arcade mode is the main attraction, but the story mode makes for a great break, and it's quite different. It adds random events between stages and allows you a limited choice of your next stage, counting down the days until the last shootout.

AFoG is a perfect example of evolutionary, rather than revolutionary, gameplay. It consists of taking something established and old, and polishing it until it shines. And AFoG gleams indeed.

reviewText:
Fistful of Gun is a top down arcade shooter that's best enjoyed with friends online or off, though it does support single player as well. It features quick round gameplay, a varied skill ceiling and some eye catching pixel art.

The premise is pretty simple. Pick from a large variety of characters, who all play very different from one another go out and shoot a bunch of stuff and dudes as the title would suggest. There are 2 main modes with a single and multiplayer variant to them. Arcade mode has you going round to round clearing the screen and at the end of the round you get to pick from an assortment of randomly generated upgrades. In story mode you can play either as a hero, or a bandit. As a hero you'll avoid innocent NPCs while shooting out the baddies. You'll get upgrades if you can find a store keep, or if you're lucky from barrels and crates. While if you play a bandit, you'll be doing similar except you'll be shooting every one, innocents be damned, and collect all the bounty from from your massacres. The balance to playing the bandit is, every one will shoot you on sight, and store keeps are rarer, as they tend to fear and run from you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulCE8PyYshw
The game's flow is pretty fast paced, some rounds only taking seconds to complete, though there will be a variety different events that may take more time. The game also runs on a limited continue system, and it's very possible to get a game over in your first few runs. It plays a lot more like an arcade classic than a modern game. Permanent gameovers, no quick save or loads, and a limited life counter are rarities in this age of gaming. Because of this, the game does benefit from faster paced style of gameplay, but that also means the game is short, can be potentially repetitive to some.

The game is a lot of fun, but there are some issues I take with it. Though the character selection is fantastic, and I love how each character are so drastically different from one another the game can feel a bit samey after an hour or two. Even with the character variety you will be shooting and dodging over and over again, with only a handful of random events that help mix things up. To be fair, the game does help alleviate some of the monotony not just with character selection, but also with game mode variety as well. The game's controls can also be an issue at times. Some characters just play better on the keyboard and mouse, while some better on the gamepad, this is mostly due to the huge degree of divergence in the characters' play style. Though this is certainly something to be admired about the game, it also does require the player to have an encumbrance of hardware ready at hand to fully enjoy the game to it's max potential. Also be aware, during our time with the game, we also ran into some bugs as well, some gamebreaking, but since the writing of this review, I have noticed dozens upon dozens of updates. It's very possible they're patched out.

Overall A fist full of Gun is a really interesting top down arcade shooter. It's not perfect, and can be repetitive for some, but it does have a lot of potential, especially if the continue to support the game with more maps, and events, as that's what I think is lacking the most.

Pros:
- Great Pixel Art
- Excellent variety in character selection
- Variable skill ceiling
- Very fun with friends online and off

Cons:
- Lacks variety in events
- Requires both keyboard and gamepad to be enjoyed appropriately
- Some re balancing required

reviewText:
A Fistful of Gun is a little western themed action shooter that looks and feels like it should be in a big box down at the arcade. It is fast and fun, has a decent selection of characters to play with, though the controls for some of them are really wonky (looking at you pablo) It has controller support and the music and voice overs are great.

The levels in story mode change based on which direction you go, so it isn't just the same maps each time you play. Arcade mode is a nice touch, it gives you a level and if you beat it, you get to choose a bonus and then are sent to another level. With high score leaderboards it adds some replay value.

It has multiplayer, though I didn't get around to testing it.

A fairly decent game all in all, and good for a quick bit of fun, despite having bad graphics.

reviewText:
Fistful of Gun is a mix of varying video game genres but most notably it is a rogue-like game if you're playing the Story Mode.

The game also features arcade mode which lets you go wild against infinite enemies in survival mode and you don't have to wait to transition into another map (like in story mode) to purchase or acquire upgrades to your character.

Of course there are plenty of characters to choose from in the game, each of them having different pros and cons and even different control schemes (which can be reconfigured).

Although I dislike low-tier pixel art games, AFoG's graphics or aesthetics is pretty good and serves its purpose well. I do have some minor grievances such as the various reloading mechanics not visible enough (revolver character), I couldn't tell from what the item did such as whiskey bottles and poison (?) bottles, etc. It would be great if they had visible text telling me which is which.

I think this game is more enjoyable as a SHUMP if it was designed as such and the terrain or background scrolled down for you. But that's just my preference.

I have yet to beat the game since it is a rogue-like and your progress is reset if you run out of continues. With that being said, I'll edit my review later whenever I get the time to actually beat the game and add more pros and cons to this review.

The game is a solid purchase, especially since most games nowadays are either buggy or uninteresting. This is a great game to pass the time from time to time. Sad that the multiplayer is kinda dead or that's just me living in a dead multiplayer region.

reviewText: This looked like it was going to be a fun little game, but I am completely underwhelmed. On a foundational level, A Fistful of Gun actually is a good game. All of the nuts and bolts that go into a solid shmup are present, but the developer decided that a classic formula should be needlessly complicated. There are a ton of characters to choose from, but there's something horribly wrong with all of them: Their movement is slow, their range of attack sucks, or their unique control scheme ranges from overly complex to nigh-unplayable. No matter which of the eleven characters the player chooses, he's hobbled in some crucial fashion. As a result, you have a game that would have been fun, were it not for a hackneyed attempt at balance or novelty (I can't tell which concern was at the forefront, but it scarcely matters since attempts at addressing either were clearly in vain).\n\nThat might have been perfectly fine, were this game not challenging enough without the need to handicap the player. You'll be subjected to some rather dense fire as you progress, and the stages are filled with environmental hazards in addition to enemy sprites. There were times when I honestly had no clue what hit, exploded, or in some other fashion killed me. Story Mode is even more difficult. It all adds up to an experience that's more frustrating than it is enjoyable. The player just feels robbed of a good time, having wandered into an unforgiving arena shooter while hamstrung by a character roster that offers a whole lot of nothing. I can tell a lot of good intentions went into this game, but paying $13 for this is a ludicrous proposition.

The menus are laggier than the gameI’m pretty sure my dog could do a better job optimizing the menus, because it looks like they forgot to make a performance report before releasing the game and ended up with about 30 different memory leaks. I get 16 FPS in the menus. I normally can’t ♥♥♥♥♥ about this considering my computer is only slightly more powerful than the Ti-84 you use to cheat on your exams, but I can complain here because I get 60 FPS in game. Why does the game run 4 times better in game? Isn’t there more ♥♥♥♥ going on when the game is running? Even better yet, the options menu gets 1 FPS. Like, no matter what settings the game is on, 1 FPS constantly. I am trying to figure out ways in which to ♥♥♥♥ up a games menu, but I can’t. I literally can’t. I have lost my ability to perceive things the same way as modern programmers. I have lost my ability to even. Time to leave the game development industry and go into something like Astronomy where I know that there will be at least a few people who have the right amount of chromosomes.

The game hangs randomlyI know that randomly generating a level can be a hard task on the processor the same way it is hard for me to find reasons to continue looking for good games on Steam, but the levels this game generates are about five pixels large. Isn’t generating a level at this point the equivalent of making a few people with Lego then dropping them onto your city-themed carpet from Shaq-height. What is so hard there? Spelunky makes a huge ♥♥♥ level without longer than 3 seconds. This game literally goes into “Not responding” mode every time you change areas. (Which is about once every 20-100 seconds.) It’s worse than running IE 6 through WINE in a Linux Virtual Machine on Windows emulated with a Mac. To quote my previous words from this review, “I literally can’t.”

Did the dev ever take a course on game design or something?Let’s do a quick survey that doesn’t involve your mom’s credit card: do you think making a game with gamepad support but then making some parts of the gameplay mouse and keyboard only is a good idea? No ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ it’s not. Then why the hell did this dev think that making some playable characters in this game mouse and keyboard only? I don’t want to use my mouse and keyboard, that is why I bought a ♥♥♥♥ing Steam Controller for the couch. Aside from that game design pit, the gameplay is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid. The dev ran over to Dennation games, stole all the source code from Hotline Miami where the character selection screen is, then instead of giving different play styles, they went a level lower. They change the control scheme from character to character. Hope you don’t like keyboard remapping, because no. On top of that, the room gets littered with bullets worse than Yuri’s brother at the end of Lord of War, WITH pigs chasing after you. Then when you die, you get to sit there and watch the countdown because apparently I care.

Small problems here and thereThis problem is more of a “white girl problem” compared to getting tackled by a bear whose cub you just ate, but the sound is ♥♥♥♥ing atrocious. It tries so hard to sound like 80s arcade games, but sounds worse than Trump when he opens his mouth. That is why I said “went crazy with the SDL audio libraries.” They put it all through some wack-♥♥♥ filter to make it sound weird. Just as a side note, it sounds like someone stapled the performance report on the snare drum so the snare sounds like its being chocked out. Another “small” problem is that the controls aren’t rock hard. In Hotline Miami, the controls are stiffer than, not gonna make that joke, but here they are fairly loose for a twitch bullet hell shooter. At this point I’m scraping the bottom of the barrel to ♥♥♥♥♥ about things, and I think I’m coming up to the review character/word limit, so I’m going to cut it off here.

Should you buy it?If you like ripping hair and triggering yourself as well have more money than know what to do with, then maybe this game is for you. But I still wouldn’t recommend it. garbo
